Title: Explosion of IBC due to incompatible substances reaction
EmergencyResponce_Descr: <p>The Internal Emergency Plan was launched following the event. This involved deploying the internal emergency team, calling the fire brigade and emergency medical services and directing the in-house staff not on the emergency team to the assembly point. The emergency team moved the injured worker away from the area affected by the event. The fire brigade arrived at the plant at 8.37 a.m., marked off the area affected by the event and secured the site. They were supported in this by the findings of an environmental check carried out to ascertain whether toxic substances were present. The worker directly affected by the event was airlifted to hospital and operated on. He died the next day.<br>Two other workers who immediately came to their colleagueâ€™s aid without appropriate protective devices suffered breathing disturbances, were brought to A&amp;E for the necessary treatment and were signed off sick for two days.</p>

AccidentDescription: <p>The accident occurred at around 8.20 a.m. on 14 January 2016 at the start of the process of filling an IBC with hydrochloric acid in 31-33% solution (fig. 1, enclosed). The accident caused pieces of the container and its protective cage to be projected outwards to a distance of around 20 m. The pieces, and in particular the metal plate on the cage of the container (fig. 2 and 3, enclose), directly hit the worker carrying out the operations, including on the face. The fire brigade arrived at the plant at around 8.37 a.m. Personnel from the emergency medical services (two ambulances), environmental protection services, occupational health and safety services and police also arrived on the scene. The seriously injured worker was airlifted to a hospital intensive care unit. The victim suffered cardiac arrest and died on 15 January 2016.</p>

Site_Description: <p>The plantâ€™s activity is the sale of industrial chemicals. It is located in an area of industrial development. On three sides it neighbours other industrial activities, whilst on the last side, separated by a road, it neighbours a kart circuit which is open to the public (albeit to members only) at times that do not overlap with the plantâ€™s working hours. Some isolated houses are located approx. 500 m away whilst the nearest built-up area is approx. 1&nbsp;km away.</p>
Installation_Description: <p>The event occurred in the area where hydrochloric acid is poured into containers. The area features four fixed vertical cylindrical tanks containing hydrochloric acid (31-33% solution) and pipes for operations to transfer it (filling truck tanks and containers for distribution to customers).</p>

Description: <p>Approx. 1.6 kg (estimated) of sodium chlorite (31% solution) present as residue in an IBC.<br> Approx. 0.5 kg (estimated) of hydrochloric acid (31-33% solution) poured into the container.<br> 0.3 kg (estimated) of chlorine dioxide produced by the reaction between the two substances mentioned above. Reaction: 5NaClO<sub>2</sub> + 4HCl -&gt; 4ClO<sub>2</sub> + 2H<sub>2</sub>O + 5NaCl<br> Chlorine gas produced by the decomposition reaction of the chlorine dioxide (ClO<sub>2</sub> -&gt; 0.5 Cl<sub>2</sub> + O<sub>2</sub>, a low-order explosion that broke apart the container).</p>

Consequence_Description: <p>The generation of chlorine dioxide through the reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium chlorite and the resulting violent decomposition reaction (low-order explosion), together with the fact that the worker closed the container when he realised that the reaction was happening and that chlorine was thus being produced, led to the explosion and caused the container and its protective metal cage to break apart. The plate on the container&rsquo;s protective metal cage (plate of approx. 50&nbsp;cm x 40&nbsp;cm x 0.2&nbsp;cm used to affix the label, required by the rules, describing the container and its content) was projected outwards by the explosion and hit the worker (who was around 1&nbsp;m from the container) in the face, causing him to die the next day.</p>
